{{Multiple issues| {{cleanup-rewrite|date=October 2013}} {{tone|date=August 2015}} }}
{{Overquotation|date=August 2015}}
'''''Applied Drama''''', also known as '''''Applied Theatre, Interactive Theatre<ref>{{cite journal|last=Sant|first=Toni|title=The Applied and Interactive Theatre Guide|date=22 Sep 2006|url=http://www.interactiveimprov.com/aitg.html}}</ref> '''or '''Applied Drama''' '''and Theatre (ADT)''''' is an [[umbrella term]] for the use of [[drama]] practice in an educational, community or therapeutic context.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Taylor|first=Phillip|title=Applied Theatre/Drama: an e-debate in 2004|journal=Research in Drama Education: The Journal of Applied Theatre and Performance J|date=February 2006|volume=11|issue=1|pages=90–95|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/13569780500437960#.UZmDvSsa-nk|doi=10.1080/13569780500437960}}</ref> It is often done in non-theatrical spaces, with participants who do not consider themselves to be artists.
There are several forms and practices considered to be under the umbrella of Applied Drama. In all these fields approaches and methods of [[Applied improvisation|Applied Improvisation]] are used.
==History and definition== Applied Drama is a term that has been contested{{By whom|date=August 2015}}, gaining popularity towards the end of the 20th century to describe drama practice in an educational, community or therapeutic context.
James Thompson states that "Applied theatre is a participatory theatre created by people who would not usually make theatre. It is, I would hope, a practice by, with and for the excluded and marginalised." <ref>{{Cite book|title = Applied Theatre: Bewilderment and Beyond|last = Thompson|first = James|publisher = Peter Lang|year = 2008|isbn = |location = Oxford|pages = 15}}</ref>
Judith Ackyroyd confirms the inclusion of both of these elements in ADT: "I have identified two features which I believe to be central to our understanding of applied theatre; an intention to generate change (of awareness, attitude, behaviour, etc), and the participation of the audience."<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Applied Theatre: Problems and Possibilities|last = Ackroyd|first = Judith|date = 2000|journal = Applied Theatre Researcher|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref>
Applied drama can be either scripted or unscripted.<ref name=":0">{{cite book|quote = |title = Applied Theatre, International Case Studies and Challenges for Practice|year = 2009|publisher = Intellect Publishers|location = Briston, UK|page = 7|editor1=Monica Prendergast |editor2=Juliana Saxton }}</ref> Some practitioners focus primarily on improvisation, whereas others introduce a range of artistic practices, such as developing scripted plays,<ref>http://www.cleanbreak.org.uk retrieved 30 November 2011</ref> devised performances,<ref>http://www.oilycart.org.uk.retrieved{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} 30 November 2011</ref> or indigenous forms of cultural performance, sometimes combined with new forms of digital communication.<ref>See, for example www.charles-royal.com, www.africanperformers.com, www.storyworkshop.org. retrieved 30 November 2011</ref>
==Fields associated with applied drama==
===Playback Theatre=== {{Main|Playback Theatre}} [[Playback Theatre]] involves audience or group members telling stories from their lives and viewing them as enacted by actors improvising. It can also be used in conjunction with [[Narrative Therapy]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=Playback theatre and narrative therapy: introducing a new model|journal=Dramatherapy |volume=35 |issue=2 |pages=108–119 |quote=Article elaborates how such integration (Playback theatre with Narrative Therapy) can be achieved and how it can contribute to the process of narrative re-authoring.|doi=10.1080/02630672.2013.821865|year=2013|last1=Barak|first1=Adi}}</ref>
===Drama in Health Education=== Drama in healthcare is drama created in medical contexts, often with the intention of rehabilitation.<ref>{{cite book|last=Warren|first=Bernie|title=Using the Creative Arts in Therapy and Healthcare: A Practical Introduction|publisher=Routledge|pages=115}}</ref>
This form of Applied Drama focuses on using theatre to educate, engage, and stimulate healing in medical professionals, patients, and the general public. Theatre and drama in healthcare are tilted towards conscientizing the populace about their health and improving their health and longevity irrespective of status or social stratification. This form of drama is often used to educate people on important health issues such as healthy eating, grief and loss, exercise, and sexual assault prevention. Examples include using actors to [[Role-playing|role-play]] health ailments in order to train healthcare professionals, performing plays focused on [[Preventive healthcare|primary prevention]], and facilitating drama workshops for patients.
===Drama Therapy=== {{Main|Drama therapy}} [[Drama therapy]] is the use of Applied Drama techniques to facilitate personal growth and promote mental health.<ref>Loretta Gallo-Lopez, Lawrence C. C. Rubin -Play-Based Interventions for Children and Adolescents on the ... 2012- Page 100 "An overview of drama therapy is provided next, along with support for the use of drama therapy with children with ASd."</ref>
Drama therapy is rooted in a clinical practice, facilitated by licensed clinicians, that stimulates language, cognitive development and builds resilience.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Clinical Applications of Drama Therapy in Child and Adolescent Treatment|last = Weber|first = Anna Marie|publisher = Brunner-Routledge|year = 2005|isbn = |location = New York|pages = |last2 = Haen|first2 = Craig}}</ref>
===Theatre for Development=== {{Main|Theatre for Development}} Theatre for Development uses Applied Drama techniques to facilitate development in [[less developed countries]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Kabaso|first=Sydney|title=Theater for Development in Zambia|year=2013|publisher=Kabsy Digital Media|location=Zambia|page=20}}</ref>
===Drama in Education === {{Confusing section|date=August 2015}} Drama in Education can allow students to develop an understanding of themselves and others.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Arts, The Ontario Curriculum, Grades 1-8|url=http://www.edu.gov.on.ca/eng/curriculum/elementary/arts18curr.pdf|publisher=Ontario Ministry of Education and Training|accessdate=20 May 2013|page=5|quote=Education in the arts is essential to students’ intellectual, social, physical, and emotional growth.}}</ref> Kathleen Galllagher has argued that 'What is clear is that there is no correct pedagogical model on offer for drama education. [...] In theatre pedagogy, we not only endow experience with meaning, but we are - as players - invited to make manifest our own subjectivities in the world evoked through character and play, a world laden with metaphor and nuance, a world where relationship to other and self-spectatorship are in dynamic and unrelenting interaction.'<ref>See 'Emergent Conceptions in Theatre Pedagogy and Production' in ''How Theatre Education: Convergences and Counterpoints'' 3-13, pp. 12-13.</ref>
===Theatre in Education=== {{Main|Theatre in education}} {{Overly detailed|date=August 2015|section=yes}} Theatre in education (TIE) originated in Britain in the mid-1960s. Monica Prendergast and Juliana Saxton cite TIE as "one of the two historic roots of applied theatre practice."<ref name=":0" /> TIE typically includes a theatre company performing in an educational setting (i.e. a school) for youth, including interactive and performative moments.
Practitioner Lynn Hoare defines TIE as a combination of "theatrical elements with interactive moments in which audience participants (in or out of role) work with actor-teachers towards an educational or social goal, using the tools of theatre in service of this goal."<ref>Hoare, Lynn. Considering the Form: Fundamental Factors in Devising for Theatre-In-Education. Thesis. University of Texas at Austin. n.p. Print.</ref>
Scholar Helen Nicholson notes that this work "involves professional theatre-makers working with young people in all kinds of educational settings and learning environments, including schools, hospitals, theaters, museums and heritage sites."<ref name=":2">Nicholson, Helen, Applied Drama: The Gift of Theatre, Palgrave MacMillan, Basingstoke, UK, 2005</ref>
TIE seeks to educate young people in issues that are relevant to both them and their communities, for example: bullying, dating violence, environmental preservation, and peer conflict resolution. "TIE companies have always been among the most socially conscious of theatre groups, consistently choosing to examine issues they believe to be of direct relevance to the lives of the children with whom they work."<ref>Jackson, Anthony, and Chris Vine. Learning through Theatre: The Changing Face of Theatre in Education. 3rd ed. New York: Routledge, 2013. Print.</ref>
"Theatre for Dialogue" (TFD) is a more recent term describing a model that was created specifically for the University of Texas at Austin campus community which pulls methods and theory from a variety of applied theatre practices such as TO and TIE. In her thesis, Spring Snyder explains that "Theatre For Dialogue performances explore the intersection between theatre and education as a way to investigate, reflect, provoke dialogue and serve as a rehearsal for reality without asking participants to share their own personal experiences. Although some of the Theatre For Dialogue’s roots originate from an adapted form of Boal’s Theatre of the Oppressed’s forum structure, it is Theatre in Education (TIE) that more closely aligns with TFD."<ref>Snyder, Spring. A Transformative Classroom Experience: Exploring Campus Mental Health through Theatre For Dialogue. Thesis. University of Texas at Austin. 2015. Print.</ref>
===Prison Theatre=== In prison theatre, practitioners engage offenders in correctional facilities, jails, prisons, and detention centers in exploring drama work often with the objective of education or rehabilitation.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shailor|first1=Jonathan|title=Performing New Lives: Prison Theatre|date=2010|publisher=Jessica Kingsley Publishers|quote=In the prison setting, as elsewhere, the needs that theatre addresses are those of self-expression and identity, freedom (of the imagination), creativity, and community.}}</ref>
Examples include Wabash Valley Correctional Facility’s ''Shakespeare in Shackles'' where maximum security prisoners learn about and perform [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]]. The University of Texas’ Center for Women and Gender Studies’ Performing Justice Project works with incarcerated female youth to learn about gender and racial justice while devising a play based on the youth’s unique experiences.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Drama Workshops for Anger Management and Offending Behaviour|last = Thompson|first = James|publisher = Jessica Kingsley Publishers|year = 1999|isbn = |location = |pages = }}</ref>
=== Theatre of the Oppressed === {{Main|Theatre of the Oppressed}}The '''Theatre of the Oppressed''' (TO) describes theatrical forms that the Brazilian theatre practitioner Augusto Boal first developed in the 1960s, initially in Brazil and later in Europe. Boal's techniques aim to use theatre as means of promoting social and political change through allowing the audience to take an active role in the creation of the show. Theatre of the Oppressed can include aspects of [[Forum Theatre]], [[Invisible theater|Invisible Theatre]], Legislative Theatre and [[Image theatre|Image Theatre]].
=== Museum Theatre === {{Main|Museum theatre}}Museum theatre aims to use theatrical techniques to add emotion and value to the museum experience.<ref name="IMTAL {{!}} IMTAL">{{Cite web|title = IMTAL {{!}} IMTAL|url = http://imtal-europe.net/|website = imtal-europe.net|accessdate = 2015-06-14}}</ref> It is typically more common in cultural institutions like heritage sites, history museums, and science and industry museums.<ref>Catherine Hughes. Museum theatre: Communicating with visitors through drama. Heinemann Drama, 1998.</ref><ref>Genshaft, Lindsay Michelle. "Bridging theatre and visual art: the role of an applied theatre practitioner in a fine art museum." (2011).</ref> As with the other forms of applied drama, it can involve a variety of theatrical techniques.<ref name="IMTAL {{!}} IMTAL" />
==See also== *[[Theatre pedagogy]] *[[Improvisation]] *[[William Shakespeare]]

{{COI|date=August 2018}} The '''Berggruen Prize''' is a $1 million award given each year to a significant individual in the field of [[Philosophy|philosophy.]] {{Infobox award | winners = [[Charles Taylor (philosopher)|Charles Taylor]] | description = A thinker whose ideas are of broad significance for shaping human self-understanding and the advancement of humanity |presenter = [[Berggruen Institute]] |website = [http://berggruen.org/prize berggruen.org] | year = 2016 }}
It is awarded by the [[Berggruen Institute]] to "thinkers whose ideas have helped us find direction, wisdom, and improved self-understanding in a world being rapidly transformed by profound social, technological, political, cultural, and economic change."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://berggruen.org/prize|title=The Berggruen Prize|website=The Berggruen Institute|accessdate=12 April 2017}}</ref> The prize jury is made out of an international panel of Nobel laureates, authors and thinkers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/1million-annual-berggruen-prize-for-philosophy--culture-awarded-to-public-philosopher-martha-c-nussbaum-300740211.html|title=$1Million Annual Berggruen Prize For Philosophy & Culture Awarded To Public Philosopher Martha C. Nussbaum|last=Institute|first=Berggruen|website=www.prnewswire.com|language=en|access-date=2018-10-31}}</ref>
The Berggruen Prize was first awarded in 2016 with the overt purpose of becoming a "[[Nobel Prize|Nobel prize]] for philosophy".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/miguelforbes/2015/11/23/berggruen-institute-launches-1m-nobel-prize-for-philosophy/#18bf9f522deb|title=Berggruen Institute Launches $1M Nobel Prize for Philosophy|last=Forbes|first=Miguel|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-10-31|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://dailynous.com/2015/10/08/a-nobel-prize-for-philosophy/|title=A Nobel Prize for Philosophy? (updated) - Daily Nous|website=dailynous.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-31}}</ref>
==Overview== The first recipient of the Berggruen Prize was the Canadian philosopher Charles Taylor, whose work "urges us to see humans as constituted not only by their biology or their personal intentions, but also by their existence within language and webs of meaningful relationships."<ref name="huffingtonpost">{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/berggruen-million-dollar-philosophy-prize_us_5602d46ae4b08820d91b1b88|title=Think Tank Creates $1 Million Philosophy Prize Because 'Ideas Matter' |date= September 24, 2015 |publisher=huffingtonpost.com|accessdate=2016-05-13}}</ref><ref name="typepad">{{cite web|url=http://leiterreports.typepad.com/blog/2015/09/new-berggruen-institute-for-philosophy-and-culture-plus-an-annual-1-million-prize.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923004224/http://leiterreports.typepad.com/blog/2015/09/new-berggruen-institute-for-philosophy-and-culture-plus-an-annual-1-million-prize.html|archive-date=2015-09-23|dead-url=yes|title=Leiter Reports: A Philosophy Blog: New Berggruen Institute for Philosophy and Culture, plus an annual $1 million prize|accessdate=2016-05-13|df=}}</ref><ref name="artnet">{{cite web|url=https://news.artnet.com/people/nicolas-berggruen-philosophy-prize-333452|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151009064208/https://news.artnet.com/people/nicolas-berggruen-philosophy-prize-333452 |archive-date=2015-10-09 |dead-url=yes|title=Nicolas Berggruen's $1 Million Philosophy Prize - artnet News|accessdate=2016-05-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/05/books/canadian-philosopher-wins-1-million-prize.html|title=Canadian Philosopher Wins $1 Million Prize|last=Schuessler|first=Jennifer|date=October 4, 2016|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=October 4, 2016}}</ref><ref>Rothman, Joshua. [http://www.newyorker.com/culture/persons-of-interest/how-to-restore-your-faith-in-democracy "How to Restore Your Faith in Democracy"], ''[[The New Yorker]],'' November 11, 2016.</ref>
The Prize is awarded yearly in December, with a ceremony at the [[New York Public Library Main Branch|New York Public Library]]. In 2016, ceremony speakers included [[University of Pennsylvania]] president [[Amy Gutmann]] and journalist [[Fareed Zakaria]].<ref>Gordon, Amanda L. [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-12-02/billionaire-s-supper-club-directs-philosopher-s-arrow-at-trump "Billionaire’s Supper Club Directs Philosopher’s Arrow at Trump"], [[Bloomberg News|Bloomberg]], December 2, 2016.</ref>
==Winners== * 2016: [[Charles Taylor (philosopher)|Charles Taylor]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/charles-taylor-mcgill-bergguren-prize-1.3792438|title=McGill philosopher Charles Taylor wins $1M Berggruen Prize {{!}} CBC News|work=CBC|access-date=2018-10-31|language=en-US}}</ref> – Canadian philosopher and [[Professor emeritus|Professor Emeritus]] of Philosophy at [[McGill University]] * 2017: [[Onora O'Neill]]<ref name="oneill">{{cite newspaper |title=Onora O’Neill Wins $1 Million Berggruen Prize for Philosophy |author=Jennifer Schuessler |date=3 October 2017 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/03/arts/onora-oneill-berggruen-prize.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref> – English philosopher and member of the [[House of Lords]] *2018: [[Martha Nussbaum]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/30/arts/martha-nussbaum-berggruen-prize.html|title=Martha Nussbaum Wins $1 Million Berggruen Prize|access-date=2018-10-30|language=en}}</ref> – American philosopher and [[Ernst Freund]] Distinguished Service Professor of Law and Ethics at the [[University of Chicago]]
==Prize jury== *[[Kwame Anthony Appiah]] – Professor of Philosophy and Law at New York University *[[Leszek Borysiewicz]] – Vice Chancellor of the University of Cambridge *[[Antonio Damasio]] – Director of the Brain and Creativity Institute at the University of Southern California *[[Amy Gutmann]] – President of the University of Pennsylvania *[[Amartya Sen]] – Nobel Laureate, Professor of Economics and Philosophy at Harvard University *[[Alison Simmons]] – Professor of Philosophy at Harvard University *[[Michael Spence]] – Nobel Laureate, Professor of Economics & Business at New York University *[[Wang Hui (intellectual)|Wang Hui]] – Professor of Chinese Language and Literature at Tsinghua University *[[George Yeo]] – Former Foreign Minister of Singapore
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{Official website|http://berggruen.org/prize}} * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o6-UcVX8Fto&list=PLyYCSKWs8iYhxJzATF5z6Owzp_O9CIwx_ Berggruen Prize Winner Charles Taylor on the Big Questions]; series of videos produced by the [[Berggruen Institute]] on occasion of Charles Taylor winning the inaugural prize. * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iN0FMBgY7rU The Berggruen Prize]; commentary of Berggruen Prize jurors such as [[Amy Gutmann]], [[Antonio Damasio]], and [[Wang Hui (intellectual)|Wang Hui]] on the significance of the Prize.
{{Philosophy awards}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Berggruen Prize, The}} [[Category:Academic awards]] [[Category:International awards]] [[Category:Philosophy awards]] [[Category:Humanities awards]] [[Category:Awards established in 2016]]

{{Infobox writer <!-- For more information see [[:Template:Infobox Writer/doc]]. --> | name = Bernardo Kucinski | honorific_prefix = | honorific_suffix = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1937<!-- {{Birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | birth_place = [[São Paulo]], Brazil | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | death_place = | resting_place = | occupation = Journalist, professor, political advisor | language = [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]], English, Hebrew | nationality = Brazilian | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = Ph.D., Communication Sciences | alma_mater = [[University of São Paulo]] | period = | genre = Essay, Journalism, Novel | subject = | movement = | notableworks = | spouse = | partner = | children = | relatives = | awards = Jabuti Prize 1997 | signature = | signature_alt = | module = | website = | portaldisp = }} '''Bernardo Kucinski''' (born 1937, in [[São Paulo]]) is a Brazilian journalist and political scientist, professor at the [[University of São Paulo]], and collaborator with Brazil's [[Workers' Party (Brazil)|Workers' Party]].<ref>[http://buscatextual.cnpq.br/buscatextual/visualizacv.jsp?Id=K4793370U9 Curriculum Lattes]</ref> He served as advisor to the President of the Republic during the first term of [[Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva]].<ref>[http://www.eitb.com/es/audios/detalle/1281556/tambien-hubo-dictadura-brasilena--bernardo-kucinski/ "También hubo dictadura brasileña", Interview to Bernardo Kucinski (EITB, March 2013)]</ref>
== Education == Kucinski graduated in Physics at the University of São Paulo (USP) between 1967 and 1968. He returned in 1986 and joined the staff of the USP School of Communications and Arts. In 1991, he earned a Ph.D. in Communication Sciences from the University of São Paulo, with a thesis on alternative media in Brazil during the period, 1964-1980.
== Career ==
=== Journalist and publisher === Bernardo Kucinski is one of the most experienced and respected journalists in the current Brazilian scene.{{according to whom|date=April 2016}} Although he graduated in Physics, he entered journalism with the encouragement of [[Raimundo Pereira]], a friend. By force of circumstances (in this case, the military regime that governed the country), he moved to England. In London, between 1971 and 1974, Kucinski was producer and host of the BBC, and a correspondent of journal ''Opinião'' first and after ''Gazeta Mercantil'', dedicated to deepen their training in economics.<ref>[http://www.portaldosjornalistas.com.br/perfil.aspx?id=14059 Profile at Portal dos Jornalistas]</ref>
Returning to Brazil in 1974, Kucinski participated in the founding of alternative newspapers including ''Em Movimento'' and ''Tempo'' (which was the first publisher in 1977). Thereafter, he worked as editor of ''Gazeta Mercantil'' and was a correspondent for ''[[The Guardian]]'', ''[[Euromoney]]'', and ''Latin America Political Report''. He also contributed to the science magazine, ''[[Ciência Hoje]]''.
=== Academic === In 1986 he joined the staff of the University of São Paulo as a professor in the School of Communications and Arts. In 1991, he presented his doctoral thesis, ''Revolutionary Journalists''.
=== Political advisor === In 2002, with the victory of the candidate of the Workers Party, Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, Kucinski becomes a special advisor to the Ministry of Social Communication of the Presidency. He left this employment in 2006.
== Awards == * Kucinski was awarded the [[Jabuti Prize]] for Literature in 1997 in Economics, Management, Business and Law, for his book ''Economic Journalism'' (1996), a result of his thesis for faculty and postdoctoral held in London. * In 2014, the German edition of his novel ''K'' was a finalist for [[International Literature Award]] - Haus der Kulturen der Welt.<ref>[http://www.hkw.de/de/programm/projekte/2014/internationaler_literaturpreis/shortlist2014/shortlist_2014.php International Literature Award]</ref> * In 2015, ''K'' was shortlisted for the [[International IMPAC Dublin Literary Award]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.impacdublinaward.ie/news/harvest-by-jim-crace-is-the-20th-winner-of-the-international-impac-dublin-literary-award/|title=Harvest by Jim Crace is the 20th winner of the International IMPAC DUBLIN Literary Award|author=Alison Flood|publisher=The Guardian|date=17 June 2015|access-date=17 April 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150908021439/http://www.impacdublinaward.ie/news/harvest-by-jim-crace-is-the-20th-winner-of-the-international-impac-dublin-literary-award/|archivedate=8 September 2015|df=}}</ref>
== Works == * ''Pau de Arara, La Violence Militaire au Brezil''. França: Cahiers Libres, 1971. * ''Fome de Lucros''. São Paulo: Brasiliense, 1977. * ''Brazil: state and struggle''. London: Latin America Bureau, 1982. * ''A ditadura da divida''. São Paulo: Brasiliense, 1987. * ''The debt squads''. London: Zed Books Ltd, 1988. * ''Jornalistas e Revolucionarios''. São Paulo: Edusp, 1991. * ''O que são Multinacionais''. São Paulo, 1991. * [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Sg8PAAAAYAAJ&q=isbn:9780906156995&dq=isbn:9780906156995&hl=en&sa=X&ei=iWgvVYLuHdDWauHNgFg&ved=0CCEQ6AEwAA ''Brazil – Carnival of the Oppressed'']. London: Latina American Bureau, 1995. {{ISBN|9780906156995}} * ''Jornalismo econômico''. São Paulo: Edusp, 1996. * ''A síndrome da antena parabolica''. São Paulo: Editora Fundação Perseu Abramo, 1998. * ''Cartas acidas da Campanha do Lula de 1998''. São Paulo: Atelie Editorial, 2000. * ''Lula and the workers party in Brazil''. London: Latin America Bureau, 2003. * ''Jornalismo na era virtual''. São Paulo: UNESP, 2005. * ''K''. São Paulo: Expressão Popular, 2011. * ''K'', tr. Sue Branford. Illustrations by Enio Squeff. London: Latin America Bureau, 2013. {{ISBN|9781899365777}}

'''Bike Arc LLC''', located in downtown [[Palo Alto, California]], is a Silicon Valley startup that designs secure [[bicycle parking rack]]s and systems. It was founded by Joseph Bellomo and Jeff Selzer in 2008. Jeff Selzer sits on the Board of Directors of the Silicon Valley Bicycle Coalition<ref>http://bikesiliconvalley.org/board/</ref> and is the General Manager of Palo Alto Bicycles. Joseph Bellomo, a [[California]]-licensed [[architect]], is the founder and owner of [[Joseph Bellomo Architects]], Inc. in Palo Alto, which he founded in 1986. In addition to collaborating on Bike Arc, Mr. Bellomo and Mr. Selzer also worked together on the Palo Alto Bikestation at the [[Caltrain]] depot.
[[File:Rac Arc by Bike Arc in downtown Palo Alto, California.jpg|thumb|Rac Arc by Bike Arc in downtown Palo Alto, California]]
[[File:Half-Arc-by-Bike-Arc.jpg|thumb|Half Arc by Bike Arc in Lytton Plaza (downtown Palo Alto, Ca.). Bicycle parking/bike rack/bike storage.]]
[[File:Umbrella Arc by Bike Arc in downtown Palo Alto, California..jpg|thumb|Umbrella Arc bicycle parking system/bike racks/bicycle storage by Bike Arc.]]
In 2009, the American Institute of Architects, California Council, gave Bike Arc the Honor Award for Small Projects.<ref>{{cite web|title=2009 Honor Award for Small Projects|url=http://www.aiacc.org/2011/08/02/bike-arc/|publisher=AIACC}}</ref>
== Philosophy ==
Mr. Bellomo and Mr. Selzer—both being bicycle enthusiasts—set out to design bicycle-parking systems that don't touch and potentially damage bicycles, a solution that prevents bicycles from contacting each other, which can cause wear-and-tear.
== Products ==
Bike Arc is [[patented]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/patents/USD604207}}</ref> in both the United States and in Europe (Office for Harmonization In the Internal Market), and the company offers multiple iterations of the same fundamental concept: a [[modular]] [[structure]] of [[steel]] arcs. The Bike Arc family includes the Rack Arc, the Half Arc, the Umbrella Arc, the Tube Arc, the Car Arc, the Bus Arc, the House Arc, and the Ad Arc.
All Bike Arc products are manufactured in the United States.
== Installations ==
The City of Palo Alto has purchased and installed multiple Bike Arc products, including numerous Rack Arcs, Half Arcs and Umbrella Arcs, and Bike Arcs are also in public spaces in Boston, Las Vegas, Redwood City, California, and Norfolk, Virginia. They have also been installed at the University of Buffalo and the University of Nebraska, as well as—among others—at Juniper Networks, Inc., Varian Medical Systems, Inc., and the Seattle Repertory Theater.

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2016}} {{Infobox organization |name = The Center for Jewish-Christian Understanding and Cooperation |image = [[File:CJCUC Logo.jpg|250px]] |alt = The Center for Jewish-Christian Understanding and Cooperation |formation = {{Start date and age |df=yes|2008|}} |founders = [[Shlomo Riskin|Rabbi Dr. Shlomo Riskin]]
[[David Nekrutman]] |location = [[Jerusalem]] |services = Jewish–Christian relations
& Bible study center |abbreviation = CJCUC |motto = "Come now, let us reason together, says the Lord"
~Isaiah 1:18 |parent_organization = [[Ohr Torah Stone]] |website = {{URL|www.cjcuc.org}} | leader_title = Chancellor | leader_name = [[Kenneth Brander|Rabbi Kenneth Brander]] | leader_title2 = Executive director | leader_name2 = [[David Nekrutman]] | leader_title3 = Associate director | leader_name3 = [[Pesach Wolicki|Rabbi Pesach Wolicki]] | leader_title4 = Director Central Europe | leader_name4 = Rabbi Josh Ahrens }} '''The Center for Jewish–Christian Understanding and Cooperation''' or '''CJCUC''' is an educational institution at which Christians who tour Israel can study the [[Hebrew Bible]] with [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox]] rabbis and learn about the Hebraic roots of Christianity. The center was established in [[Efrat]] in 2008 by Rabbi Dr. [[Shlomo Riskin]], who has been described as "the most prominent rabbinic spokesperson to Christian Zionists".{{cite journal|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/14755610.2011.633537|title=The Messiah and Rabbi Jesus: Policing the Jewish–Christian border in Christian Zionism|journal=Culture and Religion: An Interdisciplinary Journal|first=Faydra L.|last=Shapiro|year=2012|volume=12|issue=4|pages=463–477|doi=10.1080/14755610.2011.633537}} CJCUC partners with major Christian interfaith organizations such as [[Christians United for Israel]] and the [[International Christian Embassy Jerusalem]]. == History == The ideological groundwork, which led to the eventual establishment of CJCUC in 2008, began to take shape almost 50 years beforehand. In 1964, Rabbi [[Joseph B. Soloveitchik]], the teacher and mentor of CJCUC's Chancellor and Founder, [[Shlomo Riskin]], published an essay entitled "Confrontation"''Confrontation'', Tradition 6:2 p5-9, 1964. Reprinted in "A Treasury of Tradition", Hebrew Publishing Co, NY, 1967. – {{OCLC|1974913}} in which he expounded his views on interfaith dialogue and carefully drew out guidelines which permitted such a dialogue and, in the view of Riskin, not only permitted it but rendered it necessary. At around the same time, fundamental ideological shifts were forming within the ranks of the Catholic Church, and a year after Soloveitchik's essay was published, [[The Holy See]] issued ''[[Nostra aetate]]'', the Declaration on the Relation of the Church with Non-Christian Religions. ''Nostra aetate'' absolved the Jews from the [[crucifixion of Jesus]], and admitted that religious antisemitism had a significant role in laying the foundation for the atrocities perpetrated against the Jewish people. Riskin's academic plunge into Jewish–Christian relations began in the early 1960s when he attended seminars, held by Professor [[David Flusser]], about the Christian Gospels at The [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]]. As an [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox Jew]], he could pinpoint the parallels for Jesus' teachings within the Hebrew scripture.''[https://www.scribd.com/doc/93213735/gadol-2 Shabat HaGadol]'' – translated from Hebrew – page 15 After settling in Efrat, Riskin began to engage with the Christian world. Most of the Christian visitors to Efrat, those who came to hear and learn, were [[Evangelicalism|Evangelicals]]. He formed relations with Rev. Robert Stearns of Eagles' Wings and with Pastor [[John Hagee]].''[https://www.scribd.com/doc/93213735/gadol-2 Shabat HaGadol]'' – translated from Hebrew – page 18{{cite web|language=he|url=https://musaf-shabbat.com/2012/05/17/%D7%93%D7%99%D7%90%D7%9C%D7%95%D7%92-%D7%99%D7%94%D7%95%D7%93%D7%99-%D7%A0%D7%95%D7%A6%D7%A8%D7%99-%D7%97%D7%A9%D7%99%D7%91%D7%94-%D7%9E%D7%97%D7%95%D7%93%D7%A9%D7%AA-%D7%A9%D7%9C%D7%9E%D7%94/|title=Jewish–Christian Dialogue: Rethinking|first=Zur|last=Erlich|publisher=[[Makor Rishon]]|date=17 May 2012|access-date=25 October 2017}} == Activities == === Hebraic Bible Study === [[File:Riskin Nekrutman Pope.jpg|thumb|250px|CJCUC Chancellor & Founder, [[Shlomo Riskin|Rabbi Shlomo Riskin]], and CJCUC Executive Director, [[David Nekrutman]], meet with [[Pope Francis]] in [[Rome, Italy]], 26 October 2016]] [[File:Rabbi Aryeh Scheinberg event - 2 - November 2018.jpg|thumb|250px|CJCUC Founder, [[Shlomo Riskin|Rabbi Shlomo Riskin]], CJCUC Chancellor, [[Kenneth Brander|Rabbi Kenneth Brander]], CJCUC Executive Director, [[David Nekrutman]], [[John Hagee|Pastor John Hagee]] and Rabbi Aryeh Scheinberg with Israeli Deputy Foreign Minister, [[Tzipi Hotovely]], at an event held in honor of Rabbi Aryeh Scheinberg at the [[Israeli Ministry of Foreign Affairs]], 11 November 2018]] [[File:Blessing Bethlehem - Wolicki and Nekrutman.jpg|thumb|250px|CJCUC Associate director, [[Pesach Wolicki|Rabbi Pesach Wolicki]] (left), and CJCUC Executive director, [[David Nekrutman]] (right), deliver food packages as part of the center's [[Blessing Bethlehem]] fund-raising initiative to help the persecuted Christian community living in [[Bethlehem]].]] [[File:CJCUC Nekrutman Wolicki Fire Relief Halamish.jpg|thumb|250px|CJCUC Executive Director, [[David Nekrutman]], Associate Director, [[Pesach Wolicki]], and staff aiding the community of [[Halamish]] in an international relief effort carried out by the center, after a series of [[November 2016 Israel fires|arson attacks]] throughout [[Israel]] the week before left many homeless, 30 November 2016.]] CJCUC hosts Christian groups from all over the world for all-day seminars,{{cite web |url=http://www.jta.org/2008/05/29/news-opinion/riskin-to-launch-interfaith-center|title=Riskin to launch interfaith center|date=29 May 2008|accessdate=23 October 2014|work=[[Jewish Telegraphic Agency]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.worldjewishcongress.org/fr/news/13197/wjc_co_sponsors_israel_trip_of_latin_american_priests?print=true|title=WJC co-sponsors Israel trip of Latin American priests|date=1 March 2013|accessdate=24 October 2014|publisher=[[World Jewish Congress]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141024051546/http://www.worldjewishcongress.org/fr/news/13197/wjc_co_sponsors_israel_trip_of_latin_american_priests?print=true#|archive-date=24 October 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web |language=es|url=http://www.profeciaaldia.com/2016/05/zacarias-8.23-cumplido-veinte-mil-cristianos-aprende-biblia-hebrea-rabinos-ortodoxos-israel.html|title=Zacarías 8:23 se cumple: Más de 20,000 Cristianos aprenden la Biblia Hebrea con Rabinos Ortodoxos en Israel|first=Roger|last=Casco Herrera|date=16 May 2016|accessdate=20 May 2016|publisher=Profecía Al Día}} which include tours of biblical sites such as nearby [[Jerusalem]], the Path of the Patriarchs and the Herodian wells. Among the subjects that the seminar series includes are Jewish–Christian Relations; the Theology of Biblical Holidays; Covenant and Mission; [[The Ten Commandments]]; Satan, Evil and Free Will; [[Judaism]] and the Ministry of Jesus; and Human Life Created in the Image of God. The center runs educational seminars for students and faculty of Catholic and Protestant seminaries in the United States, Canada, and Europe. It has appointed North American and European directors to coordinate relations with religious leaders on these continents. CJCUC has established a Theological Think Tank, the Institute for Theological Inquiry (ITI),[http://www.standardnewswire.com/news/890647512.html "CJCUC Announces the Publication of Covenant & Hope"] – standardnewswire.com – 10 August 2012 headed by Rabbi [[Eugene Korn]] and Dr. [[Robert Jenson]] of the [[Witherspoon Institute]], which consists of international scholars and theologians whose tasks are to clarify areas of Jewish and Christian theological agreement and disagreement,''Covenant and Hope – Christian and Jewish Reflections'' – Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing Co. – July 2012 – {{ISBN|978-0802867049}} as well as identify areas of fruitful cooperation. The topics focus on past and present Jewish–Christian Relations, [[Covenant (biblical)|Covenant]], [[Salvation]], Biblical Hermeneutics, Religion and Violence, [[Ethical Monotheism]], and [[Messianism]]. In May 2011, CJCUC facilitated and sponsored a [[Yale University]] student group consisting of Orthodox Jewish and [[Evangelical Christians]] to learn the fundamentals of Jewish–Christian relations.{{cite web|url=http://hebraiccenter.org/portal/web/guest/covenant_and_witness|title=HHCC Makes Statement on Christian-Jewish Relations|publisher=Hebraic Heritage Christian Center|date=23 May 2011|accessdate=23 October 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141011065122/http://hebraiccenter.org/portal/web/guest/covenant_and_witness#|archive-date=11 October 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} In March 2012, CJCUC took Latin American priests and rabbis to learn the fundamentals of Jewish-Catholic relations in the backdrop of the Holy Land.{{cite web |url=http://www.jpost.com/Metro/Features/Priestly-blessings|title=Latin American Catholics and Jews share a trip to the Holy Land to bridge gaps|first=Deborah|last=Danan|date=3 March 2012|accessdate=23 October 2014|work=[[The Jerusalem Post]]}} In June 2012, CJCUC partnered with Christians United for Israel to bring 30 Evangelical pastors from the U.S. to learn the fundamentals of Jewish–Christian relations.{{cite web|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/765586635/Jews-and-Christian-Evangelicals-work-to-improve-communication.html|title=Jews and Christian Evangelicals work to improve communication|work=[[Deseret News]]|date=28 June 2012|accessdate=23 October 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} In February 2013, CJCUC co-sponsored the visit of more than 160 pastors to Israel through the [[Christians United for Israel]] organization.{{cite held in Broward County, Florida.{{cite web |url=http://www.sun-sentinel.com/florida-jewish-journal/news/broward/fl-jjbs-rabbi-0129-20150126-story.html|title=Riskin: Interfaith dialogue |url=http://city-sentinel.com/2015/02/rabbi-riskin-historic-curriculum/|title=Rabbi Riskin announces historic curriculum for Israeli schools during visit to Oklahoma|first=Darla|last=Shelden|date=25 [[Jerusalem]].{{cite web|language=en|url=http://www.christiannewswire.com/news/6802578149.html|title=The Land of the Bible Meets the Word of the Bible|website=Christian Newswire|date=14 July 2016|access-date=14 July 2016}}{{cite web|language=en|url=http://us3.campaign-archive2.com/?u=68fbc11d9f14b345f72e71461&id=0cd33a9201|title=CJCUC is Moving to Jerusalem|website=[[MailChimp]]|date=14 July 2016|access-date=14 July 2016}} CJCUC has received funds from Israel's Hertog family, [[Paul Singer (businessman)|Paul Singer]] Foundation, Zion's Gate International Foundation, [[Justice Ministry (Israel)|Ministry of Justice]], and [[John Hagee]] Ministries. === Day to Praise === {{Main article|Day to Praise}} In October 2014, Riskin became the first Orthodox rabbi to invite Christian visitors to Israel to participate in a "praise rally" with Jewish interfaith leaders at the Center's headquarters during the holiday of [[Sukkot]].{{cite web |url=http://www.faithnews.cc/?p=18865|title=Hundreds of Christians Joined Rabbi Riskin to Celebrate Sukkot|publisher=Christian Newswire|date=22 October 2014|accessdate=23 October 2014}} For Sukkot 2012, he hosted a seminar for Christian visitors.{{cite web |url=http://int.icej.org/news/special-reports/efrat-tour-rabbinic-view-end-days%E2%80%99|title=Efrat Tour: A Rabbinic View on the 'End of Days'|first=John|last=Black|date=9 October 2012|accessdate=23 October 2014|publisher=[[International Christian Embassy Jerusalem]]}} In March 2015, he launched the [[Day to Praise]] global initiative CJCUC, together with its founder, Rabbi [[Shlomo Riskin]], the chief rabbi of [[Efrat]], hosted an interfaith event in Efrat in which 200 Christians and Jews came together to sing the praises of God in unity. Riskin said that ''"the prayer event will help usher in the [[Messianic Age]]."''{{cite web |url=https://www.breakingisraelnews.com/51082/rabbi-shlomo-riskin-interfaith-prayer-bringing-us-closer-to-messianic-age-biblical-zionism/|title=Rabbi Shlomo Riskin: Interfaith Prayer "Bringing Us Closer" to Messianic Age|first= Adam Eliyahu|last=Berkowitz|publisher=Breaking Israel News|date=14 October 2015|accessdate=15 October 2015}} === Blessing Bethlehem === {{Main article|Blessing Bethlehem}} CJCUC created the first food voucher program to help financially disadvantaged Christian Arabs living in the Land. In September 2016, CJCUC's Associate Director, Rabbi [[Pesach Wolicki]], launched the "[[Blessing Bethlehem]]" fundraising initiative at the [[LifeLight Festival]] in [[Sioux Falls]], [[South Dakota]] in and effort to create a food giveaway program for persecuted Christians in [[Bethlehem]] and the surrounding area.{{cite web|url=http://www.argusleader.com/story/news/2016/09/02/food-giveaway-inspires-outreach-israel/89767158/|title=Food giveaway inspires outreach to Israel|first=John|last=Hult|publisher=[[Argus Leader]]|date=2 September 2016|access-date=22 September 2016}} === Social activism === In October 2013, CJCUC Executive Director, David Nekrutman published a controversial appeal for funds from Jews to support the purchase of a permanent site for the Christian-Arab church of Pastor Steven Khoury.{{cite web |url=http://jewishisrael.ning.com/page/cjcuc-s-executive-director-david-nekrutman-appeals-for-funds-to-b|title=A Call to Action|first=David|last=Nekrutman|publisher=The Jerusalem Post Christian Rabbi Riskin's Interfaith Center Appeals for Funding to Build Church in Jerusalem|work=Jewish Israel|date=27 October 2013|accessdate=23 October 2014}} In May 2014, CJCUC sponsored an interfaith Latin American clergy mission that visited the Ziv Medical Center in Safed, Israel, donating supplies to wounded Syrian civil war refugees.{{cite web|url=http://www.jns.org/news-briefs/2014/5/19/latin-american-christian-clergy-mission-visits-syrian-refugees-in-israeli-hospital#.U5q7utSSyiA=|title=Latin American clergy mission visits Syrian refugees in Israeli hospital|date=19 May 2014|accessdate=23 October 2014|work=jns.org|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141011203006/http://www.jns.org/news-briefs/2014/5/19/latin-american-christian-clergy-mission-visits-syrian-refugees-in-israeli-hospital#.U5q7utSSyiA=#.U5q7utSSyiA=|archive-date=11 2017|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} In a September 2015 piece for [[The Times of Israel]], Executive Director, David Nekrutman appealed to the Israeli [[Ministry of Education (Israel)|Ministry of Education]] in regards to budget cuts and equal funding for Christian Schools in Israel citing these budget cuts as ''"collateral damage"'' of internal political issues and stating that these issues ''"should never oppress minority populations"''.{{cite web |url=http://blogs.timesofisrael.com/collateral-damage/|title=Collateral Damage|first=David|last=Nekrutman|publisher=[[The Times of {{Infobox book | name =Colleges That Change Lives: 40 Schools That Will Change The Way You Think About College | image = Colleges That Change Lives.jpg| author = [[Loren Pope]] | country = United States | language = English | genre = Education | publisher = [[Penguin Books]] | release_date = 2006 (third edition) | isbn = 0-14-303736-6 | dewey= 378.73 22 | congress= L901 .P58 2006 | oclc= 65341249 }} '''''Colleges That Change Lives''''' is a [[undergraduate education|college]] educational guide, originally by longtime student advocate and former ''[[New York Times]]'' education editor [[Loren Pope]].<ref name="Wash Post obit" /> It was first published in 1996, with a second edition in 2000, a third edition in 2006 and a fourth edition in 2013. It concerns [[college admissions in the United States]].
The third edition profiles 40 choices for [[Liberal arts colleges in the United States|liberal arts colleges]] that, according to Pope, offer as much, if not more, than [[Ivy League]] schools: "The phrase 'Ivy League education' is an [[wikt:oxymoron|oxymoron]] when compared to the benefactions to mind and soul the colleges in this book bestow. Not only are they better, but they want you, and you will love them for making a new and better you. Your satisfaction will be lifelong."<ref>Pope, Loren. ''Colleges That Change Lives'', 3rd edition, 2006, p. 10.</ref>
==Colleges That Change Lives, Inc.== Following Loren Pope's message, '''Colleges That Change Lives, Inc.''' (CTCL) was founded in 2006 as a non-profit, [[501(c)(3)]] organization dedicated to the advancement and support of a student-centered college search process. The organization supports the goal of each student finding a college that develops a lifelong love of learning and provides the foundation for a successful and fulfilling life beyond college. According to the CTCL website: {{quote|In following Mr. Pope’s ideals, we believe that the criteria most college-bound students and their parents and counselors use, such as name and prestige, do not acknowledge the importance of understanding an individual student’s needs and how they 'fit' with the mission and identity of an individual college community.}} The organization's work is inspired by Loren Pope, who died in 2008.<ref name="Wash Post obit">Hutchinson, Carol. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/09/26/AR2008092603547.html "College Consultant Loren Pope; Commissioned a Wright House"], ''The Washington Post'', 27 September 2008.</ref> However, Colleges That Change Lives, Inc. operates independently from both the Pope estate and Penguin Books and receives no financial remuneration from either source.{{citation needed|date=January 2012}}
CTCL hosts programs during four annual tours in 26 cities in the United States and abroad. Each programs offers a 30-minute presentation about how to choose a college for fit, not rank, and then provides attendees the opportunity to speak with representatives from the 40 colleges featured in the book. The programs are free of charge and open to the public. In addition, [[Franklin & Marshall College]], [[Bard College]], and [[Grinnell College]] were formerly institutions rated by Loren Pope as Colleges That Change Lives, but were removed in later editions because the institutions became too selective.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/28/education/28face.html?pagewanted=2&_r=0&ref=teachersandschoolemployees|title = A Fighter for Colleges That Have Everything but Status|last = Finder|first = Alan|date = February 28, 2007|work = |access-date = May 10, 2015|via = |newspaper = The New York Times|department = Education}}</ref> [[St. Andrews University (North Carolina)|St. Andrews University]] (formerly St. Andrews Presbyterian College) was included in the revised edition, but removed in later editions.

{{distinguish|Darkover}} {{Infobox book | <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Novels or Wikipedia:WikiProject_Books --> | name = Dark Eden | title_orig = | translator = | image = DarkEden by ChrisBeckett.jpg | caption = Original UK cover from 2012 | author = [[Chris Beckett]] | country = [[United Kingdom]] | language = [[English language|English]] | series = | genre = [[Social science fiction]] | publisher = [[Atlantic Books#Corvus|Corvus]] | release_date = 2012 | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover|Hardback]] & [[Paperback]]) | pages = 400 | isbn = 9781848874640 | oclc = 869300938 | preceded_by = | followed_by = [[Mother of Eden]] }} '''''Dark Eden''''' is a [[social science fiction]] [[novel]] by [[British people|British]] author [[Chris Beckett]], first published in the [[United Kingdom]] in 2012. The novel explores the disintegration of a small group of a highly [[Inbreeding|inbred]] people, descendants of two individuals whose spaceship crashed on a [[rogue planet]] they call Eden.
The book won the [[Arthur C. Clarke Award]] for best science fiction novel published in the United Kingdom in 2012.
==Plot summary== The novel begins about 160 years after two human beings, Angela and Tommy, were stranded on Eden. Their three companions—Mehmet, Michael, and Dixon—left in a damaged spaceship to get help. Years passed, and although Angela and Tommy held out hope for rescue, they began to raise children and form a new society which they named "Family". Frequent and regular [[incest]] among their descendants became common, with few children knowing who their father was. Social life centers around powerful rituals: Retelling of story of the stranding, the worship of what few relics remain, myths about Earth, and the need to stay close to Circle—the place where the landing vehicle is supposed to return to, and bring them back to Earth. Social norms are strongly adhered to in this [[matriarchy]], and innovation is rare.
Family's world, Eden, is so far from its sun that it is icebound. Only a small area, which the Family calls Circle Valley, is temperate. Eden's animals each have two hearts, green-black blood, huge and lidless eyes, six legs, and tentacled feelers around their mouths. The animal population, however, is not diverse. Trees tap into the heat just below Eden's surface, bringing up warmth and providing fruit and other food. Nearly all plant and animal life on Eden is [[Bioluminescence|bioluminescent]], allowing the humans to see, while overhead the [[Milky Way]] can be easily seen at all times.
The novel centers around John Redlantern, a "newhair" (teenager) who hates the deep social and technological conservatism of Family. Killing a deadly leopard proves to be an [[Epiphany (feeling)|epiphany]] which opens his eyes to the [[Malthusian catastrophe]] facing Family, which has grown too large for its tiny valley. Supported by pretty Tina Spikestree and John's cousins (the somewhat passive teenaged Gerry and the [[club foot]]ed pre-adolescent, thoughtful Jeff), John engages in a series of [[Iconoclasm|iconoclastic]] acts which lead to the "breaking" of Family. Exile of John and his teenaged followers is only the first of many ramifications, as John leads a [[Messianism|messianic]] quest for a land "over Cold Dark" where Family can grow and thrive.
==Themes== The novel is told in the [[Narration#First-person|first-person]] voice by various characters, and each short chapter is told from a different character's perspective.<ref name=kirkus>{{cite web|url=https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/chris-beckett/dark-eden-beckett/|title=Kirkus Review: ''Dark Eden'' by Chris Beckett|website=Kirkus Reviews|date=1 February 2014|accessdate=16 April 2015}}</ref> [[Drift (linguistics)|Linguistic drift]] has given the people of Eden unique nouns ("police veekle", "rayed yoh", and "Jesus Juice" instead of "police vehicle", "radio", and "Jesus and the Jews").<ref name=kirkus /> The [[adverb]] "very" has dropped from the language, and emphasis is created by [[reduplication]] ("bad bad" instead of "very bad").<ref name=yahoointer>{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/brooklyn-baby-talk-dialect-dark-eden-exclusive-author-200811773.html|last=Beckett|first=Chris|title=Brooklyn, Baby Talk, and the Dialect of 'Dark Eden': Exclusive From Author Chris Beckett|website=Yahoo News|date=10 April 2014|accessdate=16 April 2015}}</ref> [[Linguistic relativity]] has yet to set in, so that Family lacks words to describe much of their world ("Cold Dark" instead of "high, dark mountain wreathed in glaciers").<ref name=interview>{{cite web|url=https://www.kirkusreviews.com/features/chris-beckett/|last=Goldschlager|first=Amy|title=Interview: Chris Beckett, Author of ''Dark Eden''|website=Kirkus Reviews|date=2 April 2014|accessdate=16 April 2015}}</ref> Beckett said he adopted the unsophisticated, childish language of the Edenites after realizing he had crafted a society in which "the Eden settlers were a bunch of kids and two adults... . There's no external adult world as a reference point".<ref name=interview /> With the two adults constantly speaking baby-talk to their children, pre-teens and teens never adopted more adult ways of speaking.<ref name=yahoointer />
Beckett intended the novel to be "the [[Book of Genesis|Bible story]]...turned on its head",<ref name=interview /> one in which people are "expelled to [[Garden of Eden|Eden]]".<ref name=interview /> He conceived the novel after realizing that much of the [[Old Testament]] consisted of "small domestic stories elevated to a mythical level", and he established the social norms, rituals, and myths of Family around similar stories.<ref name=interview />
Beckett also wanted to explore themes about making hard choices. To [[Thinking outside the box|think outside the box]] sometimes requires not only "transgressive" but extremely "cruel" behavior, he told ''[[Kirkus Reviews]]''.<ref name=interview /> The ramifications of John Redlantern's transgression, he noted, also has a wide number of unintended ramifications. The novel explores a socially and theologically conservative society's reaction to this transgression, which at first leads to a [[reactionary]] response. Only later does it lead to social upheaval in ways some characters predict (most notably Tina Spiketree's fears of [[patriarchy]]) but in ways no one can anticipate. Beckett said much of the latter part of the novel is about how positive, creative new ways of thinking can still harm people badly, and force people to make sacrifices they do not wish to make.<ref name=interview />
==Critical reception and awards== ''Dark Eden'' was author Chris Beckett's second novel.<ref name=clarkeaward /> Reviews were generally very positive in the United Kingdom.<ref name="kirkus"/> Stuart Kelly in ''[[The Guardian]]'' called it a "superior piece of theologically nuanced science fiction", although he noted that the novel drew a little heavily on [[Russell Hoban]]'s ''[[Riddley Walker]]'' and [[Will Self]]'s ''[[The Book of Dave]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2012/jan/13/science-fiction-fiction|last=Kelly|first=Stuart|title=Dark Eden by Chris Beckett - review|work=The Guardian|date=13 January 2012|accessdate=16 April 2015}}</ref> Author [[Paul Di Filippo]], reviewing the book for ''Locus'' magazine, described the plot as uninventive but "so splendidly [written] it feels brand new and remade".<ref name=fillipp>{{cite news|url=http://www.locusmag.com/Reviews/2013/07/paul-di-filippo-reviews-chris-beckett/|last=Di Filippo|first=Paul|title=Paul Di Filippo Reviews Chris Beckett|work=Locus|date=19 July 2013|accessdate=16 April 2015}}</ref> He pointed out that the novel's "harsh oasis" plot device resembled the work of [[Fritz Leiber]], [[Stephen Baxter (author)|Stephen Baxter]], [[Larry Niven]], and [[Karl Schroeder]]. But that didn't matter: "[A]ll this heavy categorizing misses the essence of the reader’s first contact with the book, which is pure astonishment and pleasure, a storytelling ride full of brio and wonder. ... The reader is swiftly seduced by two things that are intrinsic to, but separate from, the powerful plot: the Carrollian language, and the freaky ecology."<ref name=fillipp /> He had high praise for the character of John Redlantern, who was a [[metaphor]] (in De Filippo's mind) for both [[Moses]] and [[Cain]].<ref name=fillipp /> Harry Ritchie in the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' said "Human plight and alien planet are both superbly evoked in [this] captivating and haunting book"<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/home/books/article-2092242/SCIENCE-FICTION.html#ixzz3XUWNyECV|last=Ritchie|first=Harry|title=Science Fiction|work=Daily Mail|date=26 January 2012|accessdate=16 April 2015}}</ref> while David Langford in ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' said ''Dark Eden'' contained "A classic theme, beautifully told".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/bookreviews/9012739/Sci-Fi-roundup-January-15.html|last=Langford|first=David|title=Sci-Fi roundup: January 15|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=19 January 2012|accessdate=16 April 2015}}</ref>
''Dark Eden'' was published in the United States in April 2014 by [[Broadway Books]]. American reviewers were much more critical of the book. In ''Kirkus Reviews'', an anonymous reviewer called it "[a]bsorbing if often familiar, inventive and linguistically adept but less than fully satisfying... Enjoyable but no blockbuster."<ref name=kirkus /> Author [[N. K. Jemisin]], reviewing the novel in ''[[The New York Times]]'', praised Beckett's method of rendering "the terror of the darkness beyond the forests with a riveting deftness" and the way he "cleverly" introduced new challenges and threats to keep the reader interested.<ref name=jemisin>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/01/books/review/jeff-vandermeers-authority-and-more.html|last=Jemisin|first=N.K.|title=Science Fiction: Jeff VanderMeer's 'Authority,' and More|work=The New York Times|date=30 May 2014|accessdate=16 April 2015}}</ref> But she strongly criticized the plot for being predictable and hackneyed and the characters for being clichéd. She had harsh words for what she saw as "the 1950s ethos underpinning the whole thing. The Family has developed into a relatively peaceful communal society that venerates its elders and has necessarily relaxed sexual norms; the society John seeks to create instead is monogamous, individualistic, rife with subtle bigotries and rooted in murder. Survival and progress, the story seems to suggest, require these things."<ref name=jemisin /> ''[[Publishers Weekly]]'' thought the novel "hew[ed] too closely to historical patterns", and declared the climax very unsatisfying. The reviewer still found the changing narrative viewpoints, ecological setting, and linguistic devices interesting, however.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/978-0-8041-3868-0|title=Dark Eden; Chris Beckett, Author|website=Publishers Weekly|date=3 February 2014|accessdate=16 April 2015}}</ref>
===Awards=== ''Dark Eden'' won the 2013 Arthur C. Clarke Award for the best science fiction novel published in the United Kingdom in 2012.<ref name=clarkeaward>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2013/may/01/chris-beckett-wins-arthur-c-clarke-award|last=Flood|first=Alison|title=Chris Beckett wins Arthur C Clarke award for Dark Eden|work=The Guardian|date=1 May 2013|accessdate=16 April 2015}}</ref> Clarke Award judge Andrew M. Butler, noting why the judges gave the award to a new author rather than an established writer, said of the book, "''Dark Eden'' fuses rich biological and sociological speculation. Beckett really makes you care for characters who are stranded light years from an Earth they have never really known."<ref name=clarkeaward />
